title: 'Geostorm' trailer depicts the end of the world
title_page: 'Geostorm' trailer depicts the end of the world | Daily Mail Online
text:
If Hollywood wanted to terrify moviegoers about what a global warming-induced apocalypse would look like, it may have succeeded with Geostorm.
The latest end-of-the-world disaster film, which is set to open in theaters on October 20, is produced by Warner Brothers.
Its director, Dean Devlin, was also the writer and producer of Independence Day and Godzilla, two other blockbuster movies whose plotlines followed similar motifs.
It stars Scottish actor Gerard Butler, who plays a scientist that needs to fix sophisticated satellites that control the earth's weather.
If Hollywood wanted to terrify moviegoers about what a global warming-induced apocalypse would look like, it may have succeeded with Geostorm
The satellites suffer a malfunction that cause them to destroy the Arctic, setting off a chain of events that includes the wiping out of cities, buildings collapsing like dominoes, tornadoes that destroy markets, dead birds and frozen airplanes dropping out of the sky, and tsunami waves that flood coastal towns.
The trailer is set against a creepy-sounding cover version of Louis Armstrong's What a Wonderful World.
Butler heads an A-list cast that includes Ed Harris, Abbie Cornish, Andy Garcia, and Jim Sturgess.
The filmmakers appear to be banking on the fact that their previous efforts at end-of-the-world fear-mongering were well-received at the box office.

Independence Day, the 1996 movie about an extraterrestrial invasion that threatens the future of humanity, generated $817.4million worldwide.
Its 2016 sequel, Independence Day: Resurgence, grossed nearly $390million.
The Day After Tomorrow, the 2004 sci-fi hit distributed by 20th Century Fox, earned $544.3million at the box office.
Critics say the film bears a resemblance to another end-of-the-world apocalyptic sci-fi thriller, The Day After Tomorrow, which stars Dennis Quaid (left). The 2004 film depicts what a worldwide catastrophe caused by global warming would look like (right)
All three films were directed by German filmmaker Roland Emmerich, whose on-screen cataclysms have made him the 20th highest grossing director of all time, according to Box Office Mojo.
Emmerich is not involved in Geostorm, but it appears that his colleague Devlin is poised to carry on the disaster-flick tradition.
